title-group.article-title: Multi-step support vector regression and optimally parameterized wavelet packet transform for machine residual life prediction

article-meta.aff: Gippsland School of Information Technology, Monash University, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Muhammad Farrukh Yaqub, 4N-236 Gippsland School of Information Technology, Monash University, Churchill 3842, Melbourne, Australia Email: farrukh.yaqub@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Condition based maintenance (CBM) in the process industry helps in determining the residual life of equipment, avoiding sudden breakdown and facilitating the maintenance staff to schedule repairs by optimizing demand–supply relationships. One of the prevalent issues in CBM is to predict the residual life of the equipment. This paper proposes a novel framework to predict the remnant life of the equipment, called residual life prediction, based on optimally parameterized wavelet transform and multi-step support vector regression (RWMS). In optimally parameterized wavelet transform, a generalized criterion is proposed to select the wavelet decomposition level which works for all the applications; decomposition nodes are selected by characterizing their dominancy level based upon relative fault signature–signal energy contents. The prediction model is based on multi-step support vector regression to determine the nonlinear crack propagation in the rotary machine according to Paris’s fatigue model. The results both for the simulated as well as the actual vibration datasets validate the enhanced performance of RWMS in comparison with the existing techniques to predict the residual life of the equipment.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Machine condition monitoring (MCM) is crucial in all industrial processes to achieve high reliability, reduced manpower and scheduled maintenance. An MCM could be categorized into fault diagnosis and fault prognosis. Machine fault diagnosis has been well-explored by researchers and many works have already been published (Li and Mechefske, 2006; Chen and Mechefske, 2002; Marichal et al., 2011; Fengfeng Xi et al., 2000; Hu et al., 2007; Teotrakool et al., 2009), and also proposed by the authors (Yaqub et al., 2011a, 2011b, 2011c, 2011d, 2011e, 2011f). Relatively few of the research works cover the domain of fault prognosis i.e., one of the challenging problems is to predict the residual life of the equipment. Residual life prediction facilitates the maintenance staff to schedule the repair by optimizing demand–supply relationships rather than a sudden and unplanned breakdown of the equipment.

Figure 1 gives the flowchart for a condition based maintenance system. The first phase is to categorize the type of the fault; and many techniques have already been established in this regard. Once the fault is diagnosed, it is crucial to predict the residual life of the equipment, in contrast with the conventional techniques which are based upon plant maintenance after a specific predefined interval and are prone to sudden breakdown of the equipment. Moreover, dissembling and reassembling may initiate problems in an already smoothly running process. The proposed model can schedule on-demand and intelligent maintenance by predicting the residual life of the equipment, and repair is only advised when necessary. Figure 1.
Condition based maintenance system.

In order to predict the residual life of the equipment, it is important to record certain physical parameters such as “vibration,” which varies according to the variation in the machine dynamics. In the case of rotary machinery, malfunctioning in the operation of the bearing is the most common fault. It has been identified that 40% of total machine faults are because of bearings (Schoen et al., 1995). These bearing faults change machine dynamics and generate a certain vibration pattern that depends upon bearing characteristics frequencies. The vibration characteristic frequencies (Benbouzid, 2000) for inner race (fID), outer race (fOD) and ball (fBD) defects can be represented by equations (1) to (3): (1)fID=n2frm(1+dballdpitchcosφ), (2)fOD=n2frm(1-dballdpitchcosφ), (3)fBD=dpich2dballfrm(1-(dballdpitch)2cos2φ), where frm, dpich, dball, η and φ represent speed of rotation, pitch diameter, ball diameter, number of balls and the contact angle respectively, as highlighted in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Rolling element ball bearing geometry.

Vibration signal is non-stationary in nature, i.e., its spectral contents vary with respect to time. Wavelet transform (WT) is effectively used in order to extract the time-frequency domain contents of the vibration signal (Peng and Chu, 2004). In particular, wavelet packet transform (WPT) (Bao Liu et al., 1997; Yen and Kuo-Chung, 1999; Eren and Devaney, 2004; Peng and Chu, 2004; Teotrakool et al., 2009; Zhao et al., 2009; Eren et al., 2010; Jianhua et al., 2010; Lau and Ngan, 2010; Rodriguez-Donate et al., 2010; Kankar et al., 2011) decomposes the signal into multiple frequency nodes and provides multi-resolution analysis. The existing fault diagnostic schemes using WPT (Bao Liu et al., 1997; Yen and Kuo-Chung, 1999; Eren and Devaney, 2004; Teotrakool et al., 2009; Zhao et al., 2009; Eren et al., 2010; Jianhua et al., 2010; Lau and Ngan, 2010; Rodriguez-Donate et al., 2010; Kankar et al., 2011), use fixed predefined decomposition levels for WPT which work only for a particular application. Rather than using a predefined decomposition level, the first contribution of the proposed technique is to define a criterion for an optimal selection of decomposition level in order to determine an accurate profile of the fault-signatures.

In the case of vibration signal, the entire frequency band does not contain the true information about the fault vibration signal, just a sub-portion (Bozchalooi and Liang, 2008; Yaqub et al., 2011c) of the whole frequency spectrum contains dominant fault signatures. In wavelet packet decomposition, the vibration data is decomposed into different frequency sub-bands and feature vector is extracted from these frequency sub-bands. All the features do not contain dominant fault signatures, and redundant features degrade recognition ability of classifiers in detecting faults and redundant features degrade recognition ability of classifiers in detecting faults, so feature selection is vital along with optimal decomposition level selection. In order to extract only those features which are true representatives of the defect-related contents of the vibration signal, the second contribution of the RWMS is firstly to quantify the dominancy level of the features based upon wavelet nodes and then to select an optimal number of features.

In CBM, only a few of the techniques deal with prognosis (Heng et al., 2009). Some of these techniques treat prognosis as the classification problem, i.e., datasets captured at different values of the residual life, are used to build the fault prognostic model and the same datasets are used to validate the performance of the prediction model (Kwan et al., 2003; Hu et al., 2007; Zhang, 2010a; Zhang et al., 2010b). These prognostic models only predict the fault severity levels which were used in building the model and cannot predict the state when the severity level of the fault is different from training severity levels used in the prediction model. In Shao and Nezu, 2000; Berenji and Yan, 2006; Tran et al., 2008; Fagang Zhao et al., 2009 and Samanta and Nataraj, 2009 the predictor uses previous observations to predict the future values, known as 1-step ahead prediction. These techniques can predict the future state of the equipment based upon current observations, but cannot determine the residual life in terms of how long the equipment is going to last. In these techniques, if the step size (future time) to be predicted is increased, the prediction accuracy is deteriorated (Tran et al., 2008). Moreover, the cracks in the rotary machine components such as bearings propagate in a nonlinear way with respect to time, from inception to breakdown, as described in Paris’s fatigue model (Pugno et al., 2006). The third contribution of RWMS is to develop a novel multi-step support vector regression based prediction model which incorporates the impact of nonlinearity in defect propagation and, thereby, enhances the residual life prediction accuracy of the equipment as compared to the techniques based on simple support vector regression (SVR) (Sotiris and Pecht, 2007; Kim et al., 2009).

The paper is organized as follows: Section 2 presents the framework for the proposed technique; Section 3 illustrates the data acquisition and parameter optimization; Section 4 contains the results and validates the performance of the proposed predictive maintenance model in comparison with the existing scheme; and Section 5 presents the concluding remarks.

sec.title: 2. Framework of RWMS
sec.p:
Figure 3 gives a hierarchical paradigm for RWMS. In order to extract the time-frequency information in the non-stationary vibration signal, digitized data are decomposed using WPT (Bao Liu et al., 1997; Yen and Kuo-Chung, 1999; Eren and Devaney, 2004; Peng and Chu, 2004; Teotrakool et al., 2009; Zhao et al., 2009; Eren et al., 2010; Jianhua et al., 2010; Lau and Ngan, 2010; Rodriguez-Donate et al., 2010; Kankar et al., 2011). WPT helps in investigating the frequency contents of the vibration data in different frequency ranges, i.e., nodes. A generalized criterion is proposed for optimal selection of wavelet decomposition. Feature vectors are computed by evaluating RMS values of wavelet decomposition nodes at the selected decomposition level (Eren and Devaney, 2004; Teotrakool et al., 2009; Lau and Ngan, 2010). Not all the features contain dominant fault signatures, a criterion is proposed for optimal feature selection. Once the optimal feature vector is finalized, the predictive maintenance model is built based upon multi-step SVR. Figure 3.
Framework of RWMS.

sec.title: 2.1. Wavelet packet decomposition and feature extraction
sec.p: Among the time-frequency domain signal processing techniques, e.g., discrete Fourier transform (DFT), short time Fourier transform (STFT) and wavelet packet transform (WPT), WPT can be used for comprehensive analysis of a non-stationary vibration signal to reliably extract its time and frequency domain contents (Peng and Chu, 2004). DFT of a non-stationary signal x[n] (4) does not exploit the variation in frequency contents with respect to time. Rather it averages out the frequency content over the whole signal range (Peng and Chu, 2004). (4)X(k)=∑n=0N-1x[n]e-j(2πN)kn,k=0,1,…(N-1).

The shortcomings of DFT can be overcome by STFT (5), but STFT suffers from the problem that it yields the same time and frequency resolution for low and high frequencies. The time and frequency resolution remains the same because window size ω[n] remains constant throughout the analysis (Peng and Chu, 2004). (5)X(m,k)=∑n=0N-1x[n]ω[m-n]e-j(2πN)kn,k=0,1,…(N-1).

In order to overcome the drawback of fixed time-frequency resolution in STFT, wavelet transformation can be used, which has the tendency to perform multi-resolution analysis. Wavelet packet transform provides multi-resolution analysis, i.e., time and frequency resolution can be adjusted (Bao Liu et al., 1997; Yen and Kuo-Chung, 1999; Eren and Devaney, 2004; Teotrakool et al., 2009; Zhao et al., 2009; Eren et al., 2010; Jianhua et al., 2010; Lau and Ngan, 2010; Rodriguez-Donate et al., 2010; Kankar et al., 2011). Figure 4 gives the decomposition tree for WPT. Digitized vibration data are passed through high pass h[n] and low pass g[n] Quadrature mirror filters (QMFs) (6)–(7) and then down sampled. QMFs are finite impulse response (FIR) filters or infinite impulse response (IIR) filters (Walker, 1999). Filter selection is a very crucial part of analysing using WT. In the proposed scheme, Daubechies (Db5) filter (Yen and Kuo-Chung, 1999) is used, which is an FIR filter. Figure 4 also shows that the total number of nodes at any decomposition level is given by equation (8): (6)yapprox[n]=x[n]*g[n],yapprox[n]=∑k=-∞k=∞x[k]×g[n-k]. or (7)ydetailed[n]=x[n]*h[n],ydetailed[n]=∑k=-∞k=∞x[k]×h[n-k]. or (8)Nj=2jdecomp. Figure 4.
Wavelet packet transform.

The RMS value of wavelet decomposition nodes is computed as in equation (9), which is extensively used as feature extraction metric in the literature (Eren and Devaney, 2004; Teotrakool et al., 2009; Lau and Ngan, 2010). (9)Xrms=1N∑i=1Nxi22.

In order to elaborate the working principle of WPT, vibration data is decomposed into six decomposition levels. Table 1 lists the RMS values for the first node (lowest frequency node) in each of the six decomposition levels. It shows that the RMS value of the first decomposition node decreases by increasing the decomposition level which justifies the fact that the level of distribution of the signal energy among decomposition nodes increases by increasing the decomposition level. Moreover, Figure 5 plots the first (lowest) frequency node for each of the six decomposition levels (vibration data is for an outer race fault). The transients in the first node decrease by increasing the decomposition level which justifies the fact that by increasing the decomposition level, the distribution of signal transients is improved among wavelet decomposition nodes. Figure 5.
Coefficients for the lowest frequency node at levels 1–6.
Table 1.
Root mean square value for the lowest frequency nodes at levels1–6
1 2 3 4 5 6
1.05 0.62 0.52 0.23 0.18 0.10

The observation that the distribution of the signal transients is improved by increasing the decomposition level provides the ground for the proposed generalized criterion for optimal selection of the decomposition level. It is apparent that the decomposition level should be as high as possible, but there should be an upper limit to optimally select the decomposition level, after which the performance of the prognostic system is not improved further.

sec.title: 2.2. Wavelet decomposition level selection
sec.p:
RWMS proposes a novel criterion for optimal selection of the decomposition level which works for all the application contrary to existing schemes (Bao Liu et al., 1997; Yen and Kuo-Chung, 1999; Eren and Devaney, 2004; Peng and Chu, 2004; Teotrakool et al., 2009; Zhao et al., 2009; Eren et al., 2010; Jianhua et al., 2010; Lau and Ngan, 2010; Rodriguez-Donate et al., 2010; Kankar et al., 2011) that are application specific. The decomposition level selection is such that the high energy frequency bands in the vibration signal are split so that maximum fault signature-signal energy is achieved. The maximum fault signature-signal energy is considered such that the energy-rich nodes are decomposed into smaller frequency bands and the dominant fault signature contents lie in distinct nodes. This is because only a particular band of the overall vibration spectrum contains true fault signature, known as resonant frequency bands with maximum signal to noise ratio (SNR) (Yaqub et al., 2011c). In the given vibration signal, splitting of high energy frequency bands into multiple lower level decomposition nodes helps in identifying the nodes which are truly representative of the fault. The optimal decomposition level can be determined based on the criterion defined in proposition 1. Once the maximum fault signature-signal energy is achieved with the proposed criterion, then the signal is not decomposed further because it not only enhances the computational complexity but also increases the number of redundant features, without much gain. Proposition 1
The high energy frequency bands in the vibration signal should be decomposed into lower level wavelet nodes such that the maximum fault signature-signal energy is achieved in a node.

To study the analytical relations and expressions for the proposed scheme, let us assume that Rij represents the RMS value of the i-th node at the j-th decomposition level and Rj is the vector with RMS values for the nodes at j-th decomposition level as represented in equation (10). It is shown in equation (8) that wavelet decomposition at level j divides the overall vibration spectrum into 2j nodes. Rij gives a measure of signal energy at wavelet decomposition nodes, i.e., greater RMS value represents greater signal energy. (10)Rj={R1j,R2j,R3j,…,R2jj},

In order to achieve high energy frequency bands for the fault signature-signal, nodes are reordered in the descending order of their energy values at their respective level. Let R∧ij represents the i-th maximum value at the j-th decomposition level. Then the number of nodes NL which contain τQ signal energy can be determined from the relation in equation (11): (11)γj=NL2j,where∑i=1NLR∧ij∑i=12jRij≥τQ. where τQ represents the threshold for quantifying the node ratio containing a certain portion of the signal energy, i.e., NL is the number of nodes which contain τQ% of the signal contents in terms of RMS value. The node-ratio equation (11) is computed for every decomposition level. By increasing the decomposition level, the ratio decreases as the number of sub-bands is increased and the probability that the lesser proportion (NL2j) of the nodes would contain signal energy greater than τQ, is increased. Once the maximum signature-signal energy nodes are determined, then the node-ratio equation (11) does not change even if decomposition levels are further increased; because the least possible proportion of nodes (NL2j) has been achieved which contain signal energy greater than τQ. Analytically, the rate of change of γj with respect to j should be zero, resulting in maximum fault signature-signal energy in the nodes at that level (equation (12)): (12)dγjdj→0.

Studies were conducted for bearings faults: inner race, ball and outer race faults to determine the dependency of τQ on node-ratio equation (11), by varying τQ from 10% to 90% and it was observed (Section 4) that the horizontalness of the node-ratio (11) is always achieved at the same decomposition level irrespective of the value of threshold, i.e., decomposition level selection is independent of the threshold value, τQ. The optimal decomposition level is found to be “4”, which results in 16 feature values (equation (8)).

sec.title: 2.3. Adaptive wavelet nodes selection
sec.p: It has been investigated (Bozchalooi and Liang, 2008; Yaqub et al., 2011c;) whether only a small portion of the overall vibration spectrum contains dominant information regarding the fault-induced-vibrations, i.e., resonant frequency band and the rest is noise. In RWMS, a criterion is proposed to select the nodes containing relatively larger signal energy. The rest of the nodes with poor SNR values are discarded and not used in the prediction model which validates the robustness of the proposed scheme under poor SNR. If R∧i j represents the nodes order in the ascending order of their RMS values in equation (10), ratio γn is defined such that ND nodes are selected out of the total 2j nodes as in equation (13). The optimal value for γn is determined using parameter optimization techniques given in Section 3. Irrespective of the machine dynamics, the optimal value for γn gives the number of nodes which contain relatively higher value for signal energy, and the corresponding node indices give feature vector for the residual life prediction model. (13)γn=∑i=1NDR∧ij∑i=12jRij.

sec.title: 2.4. Residual life prediction
sec.p: RWMS develops a novel multi-step predictive maintenance system based upon support vector regression. Vibration data at different instances of the residual life are obtained and feature vectors are extracted as described in subsection 2.3. The multi-step SVR (MSVR) model works in two steps. In the first step, the two training datasets which are in the vicinity of the test query (test data-point with unknown residual life), are selected. In the second step, the SVR based prediction model is built with the selected training datasets, instead of building the prediction model with all the training data (Sotiris and Pecht, 2007; Kim et al., 2009). This enhances the overall prediction accuracy because defect propagation or RMS based feature values follow a nonlinear curve with respect to time as described by Paris’s law (Pugno et al., 2006). It explains the rate of change of defect length with respect to speed of rotation as in equation (14): (14)dadN=Co(ΔK)n. where a and N represent instantaneous defect length and speed respectively, and Co and n are material dependent constants. ΔK represents range of strength intensity. It can also be written as in equation (15): (15)D'=dDdt=CoDn.

It shows that the rate of change of defect area D is an exponential function of the instantaneous defect area. Figure 6 plots the average feature value (extracted by computing RMS value) with respect to the variation in the residual life of the equipment. It shows that the feature values used to determine the residual life of the equipment vary exponentially with defect propagation. The residual life plot is constructed by experimenting historical vibration datasets (details provided in subsection 3.1). Figure 6.
Average feature value vs. residual life.

In RWMS, partitioning the residual life divided into smaller steps (chunks) helps in mitigating the impact of nonlinear variation in the residual life of the equipment. The prediction model is developed with the data points of two training instances which are in the vicinity of the test query with unknown residual life. In order to elaborate the idea of selecting the training examples, Figure 7 gives the orientation of the data points considered at different instances of residual life, as res1, res2 and res3 (these three training data are just taken as an example, otherwise we have used more detailed datasets in the experiments which are captured at 13 different instances of the overall bearing residual life, details are provided in Table 2). Based on the position of the test query (represented as ‘star’) the training data are selected, i.e., ‘res1 = •’, ‘res2 = ▪’. In the results section, it is validated that the selection of the training data points which are in the vicinity of the test point, enhances the prediction accuracy contrary to the techniques (Sotiris and Pecht, 2007; Kim et al., 2009) based on building the prediction model by using the training data points from all the severity levels. The prediction model is built using the two selected training data which have feature values closest to the test data point with unknown residual life. The difference between the actual and the predicted residual life is exploited to quantify the performance of the proposed model. Figure 7.
Residual life prediction.
Table 2a.
Performance of RWMS (Actual)
Train Test Kernel Root mean square error Avg. root mean square error
[1 5] [2 3 4] Linear 2.5061
[5 9] [6 7 8] Linear 0.7139 1.2583
[9 13] [10 11 12] Linear 0.5550
[1 5] [2 3 4] RBF 2.2781
[5 9] [6 7 8] RBF 0.7172 1.0705
[9 13] [10 11 12] RBF 0.2162

Support vector machine (SVM) is an extensively used technique for classification and estimation (Sotiris and Pecht, 2007; Lei et al., 2009). Figure 8 gives the orientation of the optimal hyper-plane in the case when two training data are used to build the fault estimation model. The data points that are nearest to the decision boundary are called support vectors and help in calibrating the fault prediction model, represented as sv1, sv2, sv3, and sv4 in Figure 8. Figure 8.
Optimal hyper-plane in support vector machine.

In this paper, the performance of RWMS is measured by using linear and RBF kernels, which are the most commonly used kernel functions (Hsu et al., 2003; Hu et al., 2007). In the residual life prediction model, labels are only defined to determine the orientation of the optimal hyper-planes, otherwise SVM also gives the probabilistic measure for the nearness and furthest distance of the test data point from the training data points (Platt, 1999). In support vector regression (SVR), the optimal regression hyper-planes are determined that best fit the training datasets.

sec.title: 3.1. Actual data acquisition
sec.p:
The data were generated by NSF I/UCR Center on Intelligent Maintenance Systems(IMS) with support from Rexnord Corp. in Milwaukee, WI (Qiu et al., 2003). Four bearings were installed on one shaft. The speed of rotation was kept constant at 2000 RPM with a radial load of 6000 lb. On each bearing two PCB 353B33 High Sensitivity Quartz ICP accelerometers were installed for a total of eight accelerometers (one vertical Y and one horizontal X on each). Figure 9 shows the test rig and illustrates sensor placement. All failures occurred after exceeding the designed life time of the bearings, which is more than 100 million revolutions. Vibration data were recorded after every 10 minutes for the period of 02/12/2004 10:32:39 – 02/19/2004 06:22:39 using a NI DAQ Card 6062E. At the end of the test-to-failure experiment an outer race failure occurred on bearing 1. Figure 9.
Experimental setup. Reproduced with kind permission from Elsevier (Qiu et al., 2003).

sec.title: 3.2. Simulated vibration data
sec.p: For simulation studies of RWMS, vibration data for the bearing faults based on the transfer function with continuous hammering of the rotary machine has been used (Ocak and Loparo, 2004). The transfer function (equation (16)) uses the most common input forces for the vibration signal, i.e., mass unbalance, misalignment of the shaft and bearing defect are given by equations (17)–(19) respectively: (16)H(s)=2.283s4+642.6s3+4.457×108s2(s4+619.3s3+4.42×108s2+4.234×1010s +5.697×1015 ), (17)Fmass-unbalance=A1cos(2πfst+θ1), (18)Fmisalignment=fs∑k=1NmAkmcos(2πkfst+θmk), (19)Fbearing=fs∑k=1NbAkbcos(2πkfbt+θbk).

The harmonic amplitude A, number of harmonics N, phase relationships θ, speed of rotation fs and bearing defect frequencies fb are adjusted for these forces to simulate the vibration data for inner race, ball and outer race faults with different residual life (Ocak and Loparo, 2004). In order to determine the robustness of the proposed system, the simulated data is obtained at poor SNR, ie., 0 dB.

sec.title: 3.3. Parameters optimization
sec.p: There are five parameters to be optimized; decomposition level (ndecomp), number of nodes (ND), regularization parameter C, RBF kernel γk and epsilon ɛ. Two of the parameters: ndecomp and ND are related to wavelet decomposition, and the rest of the parameters i.e., C, γk and ɛ belong to SVR (Platt, 1999). Results for optimizing ndecomp and ND are presented in detail in Section 4. The applicability of the proposed generalized criterion for the optimal selection of the decomposition level is also presented. In order to optimize the SVR parameters, i.e., C, γk and ɛ, vibration data are divided into two subsets – training dataset and test dataset. The details of the training datasets are provided in subsection 4.1. Training datasets are used to optimize the parameters in the prediction model using 5-fold cross validation (Hsu et al., 2003). Root mean square error (RMSE) is minimized as quantification metric in parameters optimization, which is a measure of the mismatch between the actual residual life (obtained from the historical data) and the predicted residual life (obtained from the prediction model). The greater the value of RMSE, the poorer is the performance of the predictor and vice versa. (20)RMSE=(∑i=1N(Actual Residual Lifei -Predicted Residual Lifei)2 )N2.

sec.title: 4. Experimental results
sec.p: This section presents the results to validate the performance of RWMS. The performance is measured in terms of RMSE value. The first part of this section presents the performance evaluation of RWMS. The impact of optimization parameters, i.e., optimal decomposition level selection, dominant decomposition nodes selection and multi-step SVR is presented in Sections 4.2 to 4.4. The last part compares the performance of RWMS with the existing techniques.

sec.title: 4.1. Performance evaluation of RWMS
sec.p:
Tables 2a and 2b present the results for the residual life prediction in RWMS for the actual (Table 2a) and the simulated (Table 2b) datasets. The experimental datasets are used for 13 levels, level-1 corresponds to the data when remnant life of the equipment is 100% and level-13 corresponds to the point when the remaining life of the equipment is 0%. The regression model parameters are optimized as described in subsection 3.3 using the training data given in Tables 2a and 2b, and performance is validated using the test data. In the proposed framework, the first phase of prediction starts with selecting the training examples which surround the test query. In the second phase, the residual life is predicted by building the prediction model with the selected training examples. Performance of the prediction model is quantified using equation (20). Tables 2a and 2b show that the residual life prediction model is divided into three steps, i.e., [1 → 5], [5 → 9] and [9 → 13]. The performance of the proposed model is measured using linear as well as RBF kernel. The prediction accuracy is better in the case of the RBF kernel as compared with the linear kernel as it has a tendency to define boundaries for nonlinearly separable datasets (Hsu et al., 2003). The prediction accuracy for simulated vibration datasets (Table 2b) is poorer compared with the actual vibration datasets (Table 2a), because in order to determine the robustness of the proposed system, the simulated data is obtained at poor SNR, i.e., 0 dB. Table 2b.
Performance of RWMS (Simulated: 0 dB)
Train Test Kernel Root mean square error Avg. root mean square error
[1 5] [2 3 4] Linear 3.7169
[5 9] [6 7 8] Linear 0.4711 1.5840
[9 13] [10 11 12] Linear 0.5638
[1 5] [2 3 4] RBF 2.9435
[5 9] [6 7 8] RBF 0.4700 1.2922
[9 13] [10 11 12] RBF 0.4632

sec.title: 4.2. Impact of decomposition level selection
sec.p:
Figures 10(a) to 10(d) present the results for optimal selection of decomposition level. The node ratio γj in equation (11) is plotted against the decomposition level for different value of the thresholds τQ (30%, 60% and 90%). The ratio corresponds to the number of nodes containing τQ% of the signal RMS value to the total number of nodes at a particular decomposition level. The results are presented for the training vibration datasets in Table 2: Figure 10(a) (level-1), Figure 10(b) (level-5), Figure 10(c) (level-9) and Figure 10(d) (level-13). Figures 10(a) to 10(d) show that if the number of the decomposition level is increased then the node-ratio decreases to a certain extent and then gets flattened. The overall variation in the value of γj in Figures 10(a) to 10(d) shows that the optimal decomposition level is “4”, after which there is no significant variation in the ratio and the curves are smoothed. These curves are obtained for different values of τQ. At a lower value of τQ, i.e., 30%, it looks as if it is appropriate to select the higher decomposition level rather than “4”. But once a smooth behavior is achieved in the variation of γj, opting for higher decomposition level not only enhances the computational complexity but also causes degradation in the prediction accuracy due to a large number of redundant features. Figure 10.
(a). Optimal decomposition level selection, level-1; (b). Optimal decomposition level selection, level-5; (c). Optimal decomposition level selection, level-9; (d). Optimal decomposition level selection, level-13.

In order to further elaborate the working of the proposed scheme, Tables 3a and 3b list the prediction accuracy by varying the decompostion level for the actual (Table 3a) and the simulated (Table 3b) vibration datasets. It shows that by increasing the decomposition level, prediction accuracy is improved at the beginning. However, if the decomposition level is increased beyond “4” (optimal decompostion level), the prediction accuracy starts decreasing because the number of features increases exponentially with the rise in the decomposition level. This unnecessarily large number of features not only deteriorates prediction accuracy but also costs extra computational overhead. Table 3a.
RMSE vs. WPT Level (Actual)
Level RMSE (Linear) RMSE (RBF)
1 2.2186 1.3448
2 2.1003 1.4037
3 1.9277 1.3658
4 1.2583 1.0705
5 1.5959 1.2620
6 1.7992 1.4218
7 2.0443 1.5369
8 2.0877 1.7682
Table 3b.
RMSE vs. WPT Level (Simulated)
Level RMSE (Linear) RMSE (RBF)
1 2.1807 1.3333

sec.title: 4.3. Impact of decomposition nodes selection
sec.p: RWMS emphasizes the need for the optimal selection of the decomposition nodes rather than building the prediction model with all the nodes.

Tables 4a and 4b present the results both for “linear” and “RBF” kernel in case of the actual and the simulated vibration datasets, in order to substantiate the need for the selection of the dominant decomposition nodes. It shows that the prediction accuracy is maximum (RMSE is minimum) when node ratio γn=0.4 both for the actual (Table 4a) and the simulated vibration datasets (Table 4b). The optimal selection of the decomposition nodes not only enhances the prediction accuracy but also reduces the complexity of the prediction model by decreasing the number of decomposition nodes, i.e., features. Table 4a.

sec.title: 4.4. Impact of multi-step prediction
sec.p:
Tables 5a and 5b present the performance evaluation by varying the number of steps in RWMS for the actual and the simulated vibration datasets. As the defect propagation is nonlinear as described in Figure 6, by increasing the number of steps, accuracy is improved because more detailed historical data is used. The overall framework is still the same, the training examples which are in the vicinity of the test query are selected from the overall training datasets and prediction model is built. The increase in the number of steps results in representing overall life of the bearing in smaller chunks, so the prediction accuracy is improved. Table 5a.
Multi-step prediction (actual)
Experimental setup Root mean square error (linear) Root mean square error (RBF)
2-Steps Prediction 3.9280 2.7492
3-Steps Prediction 1.2583 1.0705
4-Steps Prediction 1.0771 0.8364
Table 5b.
Multi-step prediction (simulated)
Experimental Setup Root mean square error (linear) Root mean square error (RBF)
2-Steps Prediction 5.1454 3.9171
3-Steps Prediction 1.5840 1.3190
4-Steps Prediction 1.0927 0.8375

sec.title: 4.5. Comparative performance evaluation
sec.p:
This subsection presents performance evaluation of the proposed technique in comparison with 1-step ahead prediction (Shao and Nezu, 2000; Berenji and Yan, 2006; Tran et al., 2008; Fagang Zhao et al., 2009; Samanta and Nataraj, 2009) and SVR (Sotiris and Pecht, 2007; Kim et al., 2009) techniques. Table 6a gives the performance evaluation for the actual vibration datasets and Table 6b presents results for the simulated vibration datasets. The conventional SVR is based on building the prediction model by using all the training data captured at different instances of the bearing life time. The performance of the 1-step ahead prediction techniques is quantified by building the prediction model with the past historical vibration datasets and a future state is predicted. Due to nonlinear crack propagation, the techniques based on conventional SVR and 1-step ahead prediction do not precisely determine the future state of the machine. Moreover, the prediction accuracy of these techniques deteriorates further if the number of prediction steps is increased. The performance of proposed RWMS is presented for prediction in 3-steps, if the number of different instances when vibration data are captured at different timestamps of the residual life is increased further, predication accuracy is improved (Table 5). Overall, RWMS guarantees performance enhancement in terms of residual life prediction accuracy of the rotary equipment. Table 6a.
Comparative performance evaluation (actual)
Experimental setup Root mean square error (linear) Root mean square error (RBF)
Conventional SVR 9.8752 4.7955
1-Step Ahead 5.9561 2.1715
RWMS 1.2583 1.0705
Table 6b.
Comparative performance evaluation (simulated)
Experimental setup Root mean square error (linear) Root mean square error (RBF)
Conventional SVR 9.9095 9.7756
1-Step Ahead 8.8266 2.6046
RWMS 1.5840 1.2922

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: This paper proposes a novel framework for residual life prediction of rotary equipment based on optimally parameterized wavelet transform and multi-step support vector regression. In optimally parameterized wavelet transform, a generalized criterion is proposed for optimal selection of the decomposition level as well as decomposition nodes. The criterion for decomposition level selection defines an upper limit on the decomposition level. Optimal decomposition nodes selection does not only enhance the prediction accuracy, but it also reduces the complexity. The ‘multi-step’ regression model further enhances the prediction accuracy as compared to the existing techniques by incorporating the impact of nonlinear defect propagation. The overall performance of the RWMS in terms of prediction accuracy justifies the efficacy of the proposed scheme in industrial processes to predict the residual life of the equipment.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
